turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- you don't lift yourself into a cause of action because there may be a reference in the Commission.

turn.speaker: morton_hollander
turn.label: Mr. Morton Hollander
turn.text: No.

I'm not suggesting and I'm -- I'm just suggesting that the cause of action is not destroyed as petitioners contended is, simply because the Court is not empowered to pass on the question of reasonableness.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Mr. Hollander, tell me, I think that this probably germane to the argument you're making.
If there's a determination that the charged rate is unreasonable, what then goes to the fact of the Court, just that determination that the charged rate was unreasonable?

turn.speaker: morton_hollander
turn.label: Mr. Morton Hollander
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.
I assume that that --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Then what -- what then determines the amount that should be paid?

turn.speaker: morton_hollander
turn.label: Mr. Morton Hollander
turn.text: Well, ordinarily the Commission determination in a situation of this sort will be framed along these lines that the charge is unreasonable to the extent that it exceeds so much.
Now, for example, we hope if we're allowed to go before the commission on the -- in the T. I. M. E. case to show that the joint rate is unreasonable to the extent that it exceeds a combination --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: When I suppose you failed on that but the Commission says, Well, it's unreasonable to the extent it exceeds 8 cents.

turn.speaker: morton_hollander
turn.label: Mr. Morton Hollander
turn.text: Yes.
And then --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Now, the --then well what's the judgment then, that's entered?

turn.speaker: morton_hollander
turn.label: Mr. Morton Hollander
turn.text: The judgment which is -- well --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: You pay 6.5 --

turn.speaker: morton_hollander
turn.label: Mr. Morton Hollander
turn.text: -- in this case --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: -- for something like that?

turn.speaker: morton_hollander
turn.label: Mr. Morton Hollander
turn.text: Yes.
In this case, for example, we paid 6.5, judgment would be entered for 7.5 or (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: In other words --

turn.speaker: morton_hollander
turn.label: Mr. Morton Hollander
turn.text: Whatever the difference is between the paid rate and the --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well that -- well that's what I'm trying to get to.
In other words, the -- what finally then is the issue and dispute.
The proper rate to be determined is determined by the Commission entirely and the court acts merely as administratively somehow, to enter a judgment for whatever the right rate is, isn't that it?

turn.speaker: morton_hollander
turn.label: Mr. Morton Hollander
turn.text: Yes.
On that phase of the case, it certainly does.
But it may have preliminary and threshold questions to cope with and as it does in any suit, for example, against the United States under the Tucker Act.
It may have serious limitation questions to -- to cope with which it would necessarily consider wholly independently.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: But -- but if a judgment is entered, it has to be a judgment determined by the conclusions of the Commission as to what the proper rate is.

turn.speaker: morton_hollander
turn.label: Mr. Morton Hollander
turn.text: Well, I am -- frankly, I'm not ready to take a position as to the extent to which the rate determined by the Commission where -- to the extent to which the courts are foreclosed from judicial review --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: May I suggest, I think, you're wise and I'd finally take it.

turn.speaker: morton_hollander
turn.label: Mr. Morton Hollander
turn.text: -- of the -- of the rate.
I think that question probably will be up here in about two years.

I also would like to -- to point that, Mr. Justice Brennan, that even under -- even under Part I, where there is -- even under Part I where there is the Commissioner agrees explicit reparations authority that is in favor of the shipper against the rail carrier -- even such an award by the Commission is -- is only a prima facie award and subject, of course, to -- to review in the courts.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: morton_hollander
turn.label: Mr. Morton Hollander
turn.text: In -- in effect, I think that's right, Your Honor.
I -- I think that that's the role the -- the Commission occupies you and it necessarily has to assume the role because there is no other master or referee for the courts to turn to.
They -- they have to turn to this -- to this one body which does have the expertise on this question.
And I think it's all together sensible and reasonable for the courts to do it, because in that way, you're effectuating the purpose of the Motor Carrier --

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: morton_hollander
turn.label: Mr. Morton Hollander
turn.text: Well, as I pointed out before, I'm not quite sure as to the extent to which the Commission's decision is necessarily binding on the referral court.
I think that question is -- is pending now in -- in other litigation.

I do think that the minimum relief we're entitled to though, is to get this Commission's determination and then it may very well be that the parties both will be willing to fully abide by the Commission's resolution of the question and that, of course, will -- will put an end to the controversy.
How --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: That you -- that you would, now -- did you just indicate a doubt whether the referring court or the (Inaudible) would be bound by the determination of the Commission on the rates, on the reasonableness of the rates?
It should (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: morton_hollander
turn.label: Mr. Morton Hollander
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But you expressed the doubt and you get yourself into the -- into the box that you said you ought not to get into, namely, that you may have diverse views on questions of rates of different courts A and B that you may have the court determine the reasonableness of the rate, if it has no business here.

turn.speaker: morton_hollander
turn.label: Mr. Morton Hollander
turn.text: Well, a -- the -- the courts, of course, as Your -- as Your Honor knows, have, at all times, reviewed Interstate Commerce Commission orders and that doesn't necessarily mean that they're ready to substitute their own judgment for that of the administrative agency, they go over the administrative record, they determine whether it's an arbitrary decision.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Not -- not the only basis for reversing here.

turn.speaker: morton_hollander
turn.label: Mr. Morton Hollander
turn.text: Find out where there was any substantial basis in it.
And to that, that was the only extent to which I -- I met to infer that that is not binding.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: You're not talking about a statutory three-judge court?

turn.speaker: morton_hollander
turn.label: Mr. Morton Hollander
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.
Yes.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: You're doing an -- an original --

turn.speaker: morton_hollander
turn.label: Mr. Morton Hollander
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: morton_hollander
turn.label: Mr. Morton Hollander
turn.text: Actually, the Davidson case, the -- the one Mr. Justice Douglas referred to at 302 I.C.C., is actually -- there was an opinion -- a decision by the Commission on reference from a District Court and it is now, I think, being reviewed by a one-judge court on the theory that this is actually a complaint for money damages.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well, that's unusual, isn't it, a review of a rate determination by the Commission by a single judge?

turn.speaker: morton_hollander
turn.label: Mr. Morton Hollander
turn.text: Well, it's not unusual where all that is sort is reparations, Your Honor.
That is the -- that -- that is the -- there is a special statutory provision with respect to the monetary reparations and awards.
But as I say, I would prefer not to be drawn in to any controversies to what might happen two years from now.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Either one of the --

turn.speaker: morton_hollander
turn.label: Mr. Morton Hollander
turn.text: I think --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Either on of the dilemmas (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: morton_hollander
turn.label: Mr. Morton Hollander
turn.text: All we're asking -- all we're asking for here is an opportunity to have our day in court to establish our defense to the satisfaction of the Interstate Commerce Commission.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: I don't quite understand why the -- this thing that I had exposed, the Abilene case, the courts have held that in case where it is proper to determined reasons.
It was right to submit it to the I.C.C. that determine reasonableness -- this is all we did.
And that the courts would leave that alone unless they would upset an order of the Commission and in that respect, just the same as it would in any other.
Hasn't that been the rule?

turn.speaker: morton_hollander
turn.label: Mr. Morton Hollander
turn.text: I think so, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: I.C.C. has practically served as a (Inaudible) on the questions of reasonableness in proper cases, I'm not saying it should in proper cases.
But assuming it's the proper case, I would suppose that there's been some extraordinary reason for upsetting its finding of reasonableness should be followed like any other case.

turn.speaker: morton_hollander
turn.label: Mr. Morton Hollander
turn.text: I think so, Your Honor.
I -- I, myself, see no real room for -- for any dispute on that question.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Your dispute is whether or not it's proper to have accepted in thisway.

turn.speaker: morton_hollander
turn.label: Mr. Morton Hollander
turn.text: Yes, and we think that in the circumstances of this case just as in Western Pacific, it was not only proper, it was not only appropriate, but it was mandatory on the District Court in both cases to afford us an opportunity to establish our defense of unreasonableness before the only body charged by Congress with the responsibility for adjudicating that question, namely Interstate Commerce Commission.
Thank you.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Mr. Rea.

turn.speaker: bryce_rea_jr
turn.label: Mr. Bryce Rea, Jr.
turn.text: Thank you, Mr. Chief Justice.
I would like to take just a minute to suggest that Mr. Justice Frankfurter and his colleagues in their dissent in the Montana-Dakota case do not dissent from the proposition which we urge.

I would like to quote Mr. Justice Frankfurter's language at page 258 of 341 U.S., Despite the unqualified statutory declaration that unreasonable rates are unlawful, which is the precise declaration upon which the respondent relied here, we think it clear that Congress did not intend either court or Commission to have the power to award reparations on the ground that a properly filed rate or charge has in fact been unreasonably high or low.
If that were all the complaint before us, showed, and if I may interpolate, that is all the proceedings here shows.
There is no allegation, but that the rates of Davidson and the rates of T. I. M. E. were properly established.
If that were all the complaint before us showed, we would agree that recovery of damages in a civil action would not be an appropriate remedy and that the complaint should have been dismissed.
Now, we submit that that language which is squarely in accord with the language of the majority in that opinion, on that point relating to properly filed rates, controls here.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Suppose you had filed a rate today, $50 per pound, would that be binding until --

turn.speaker: bryce_rea_jr
turn.label: Mr. Bryce Rea, Jr.
turn.text: This would have to --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: -- (Voice Overlap) the company's action mistaken?

turn.speaker: bryce_rea_jr
turn.label: Mr. Bryce Rea, Jr.
turn.text: Mr. Justice Black, if we file the rate, it was clearly excessive.
The Commission would promptly, on its own motion, suspend that rate for a period of seven months.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Suppose it -- if somebody paid you under protest, would they have any remedy?

turn.speaker: bryce_rea_jr
turn.label: Mr. Bryce Rea, Jr.
turn.text: Once the rate properly takes effect and is applicable, filed with the Commission and effective, the shipper has no remedy.
No, Your Honor, as long as that rate is filed and effective.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: But if --

turn.speaker: bryce_rea_jr
turn.label: Mr. Bryce Rea, Jr.
turn.text: No he could (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: (Voice Overlap) make it effective?

turn.speaker: bryce_rea_jr
turn.label: Mr. Bryce Rea, Jr.
turn.text: He could challenge it.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Yes, he could challenge.

turn.speaker: bryce_rea_jr
turn.label: Mr. Bryce Rea, Jr.
turn.text: I've -- I understood you to mean, does he have any remedy by way of recovery back.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: I suppose -- suppose you make him pay it before he can challenge it, what's his remedy?

turn.speaker: bryce_rea_jr
turn.label: Mr. Bryce Rea, Jr.
turn.text: He has no remedy as far as recovering back is concerned.
His remedy is to go to the Commission, file a complaint and ask the Commission to declare that rate unjust and unreasonable and to order the carrier to --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Does that help?

turn.speaker: bryce_rea_jr
turn.label: Mr. Bryce Rea, Jr.
turn.text: -- substitute to other forms.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Does that help him with reference to the rate he's already paid?

turn.speaker: bryce_rea_jr
turn.label: Mr. Bryce Rea, Jr.
turn.text: It does not help him, Your Honor, with reference to the shipment that has already moved at that rate.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: There are no refunds?

turn.speaker: bryce_rea_jr
turn.label: Mr. Bryce Rea, Jr.
turn.text: No refund is permissible.
No, Your Honor, any more than it was permissible in Montana-Dakota.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: However unreasonable, it might be held to be?

turn.speaker: bryce_rea_jr
turn.label: Mr. Bryce Rea, Jr.
turn.text: However unreasonable as of theoretical matter, Your Honor, it could be a ridiculous rate.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well, that's -- that could (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: bryce_rea_jr
turn.label: Mr. Bryce Rea, Jr.
turn.text: And it could be --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: That's what the Government claims here.

turn.speaker: bryce_rea_jr
turn.label: Mr. Bryce Rea, Jr.
turn.text: It could be that for some reason or other, the Interstate Commerce Commission fails to suspend it and it takes effect.
And it's six months before it's cancelled and in the meantime, practically to be done with.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: In the meantime, all payments made on it --

turn.speaker: bryce_rea_jr
turn.label: Mr. Bryce Rea, Jr.
turn.text: That's right, I would say --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: -- not that because it's filed.

turn.speaker: bryce_rea_jr
turn.label: Mr. Bryce Rea, Jr.
turn.text: I would suggest to Your Honor --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: That may be right.
I'm just asking if that --

turn.speaker: bryce_rea_jr
turn.label: Mr. Bryce Rea, Jr.
turn.text: That is a theoretical possibility that --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: I'm not talking about theoretical.
I'm talking about actual.
I -- I thought you -- what you're saying is maybe it's right.

turn.speaker: bryce_rea_jr
turn.label: Mr. Bryce Rea, Jr.
turn.text: I am saying, Your Honor --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: bryce_rea_jr
turn.label: Mr. Bryce Rea, Jr.
turn.text: -- yes, as a matter of law -- as a matter of law, Davidson could file a rate tomorrow, $100 per hundred for transportation from Baltimore to Washington.
And it's possible that the Commission would not take any action on until 45 days have passed, in which event --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: But suppose (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: bryce_rea_jr
turn.label: Mr. Bryce Rea, Jr.
turn.text: -- in which to that -- take effect at the end of 30 and it would be 15 days during which that rate was in effect.
It's possible that a shipper might move some traffic under that rate and pay that $100 rate.
If that happens, he would have, under the law, no refund.
But as a practical matter, the Commission would not let that rate stay on in and there's a --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: No, not that time.

turn.speaker: bryce_rea_jr
turn.label: Mr. Bryce Rea, Jr.
turn.text: As a practical matter, the Davidson Transfer & Storage Company, faced with the vicious competition of other motor carriers between Washington and Baltimore was never violated.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: And I --

turn.speaker: bryce_rea_jr
turn.label: Mr. Bryce Rea, Jr.
turn.text: And if he did file it, no shipper would give him any business.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: But suppose instead of that, they just made the combined rate, if you shipped it all the way through four times what the rate would be if he divided up into parts, but to be in a refund there, if the Court -- if the Commission should later find that to be unreasonable.

turn.speaker: bryce_rea_jr
turn.label: Mr. Bryce Rea, Jr.
turn.text: Are you referring, Justice Black, to the situation where you have a rate from Washington to Baltimore, and rate from Baltimore to Philadelphia and then another rate Washington to Philadelphia?

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: (Voice Overlap) Philadelphia to Harrisburg is another -- from Harrisburg to [Laughs] New York.

turn.speaker: bryce_rea_jr
turn.label: Mr. Bryce Rea, Jr.
turn.text: In the event you would have a series of rates, a shipper can get the benefit of those rates if he wants to ship his goods from Washington to Baltimore and then reship them from Washington to Philadelphia and then reship them from Philadelphia to Trenton and then reship them from Trenton to New York.
In that situation, he paid that combination of local rates.

If however, he tenders his shipment to Davidson Transfer & Storage Company in its Washington terminal, under a bill of lading calling for delivery in New York through shipments, he must pay the through rate published and applicable to that through movement.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: He must pay it and however unreasonable, it might later be found to be, his money is gone.

turn.speaker: bryce_rea_jr
turn.label: Mr. Bryce Rea, Jr.
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: There is no remedy.

turn.speaker: bryce_rea_jr
turn.label: Mr. Bryce Rea, Jr.
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Over the period or prior to the period that he has filed a reparation suit challenging the reasonableness of the joint excessive rate?

turn.speaker: bryce_rea_jr
turn.label: Mr. Bryce Rea, Jr.
turn.text: He -- he has no recovery for anything he has paid --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: bryce_rea_jr
turn.label: Mr. Bryce Rea, Jr.
turn.text: -- while that rate is in effect.
His remedy, as Mr. Justice Frankfurter pointed out in the Montana-Dakota case, is to go to the Commission and say this rate is unreasonable.
We want you to find it unreasonable and we want you to order the carrier to put in a new one.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: If suppose -- suppose -- suppose the exacted today, he goes to the Commission today.
He has to pay it and not get his goods shipped.
The Commission takes it up and decides a year later that it was all together unreasonable.Can he get anything back?

turn.speaker: bryce_rea_jr
turn.label: Mr. Bryce Rea, Jr.
turn.text: He cannot get anything back for that movement that moved today.
No, Your Honor.
The Commission will issue an order which is the only power the Commission has to make the rates change prospective.

I would say this, if I can just in one further answer, Mr. Justice Black, as a practical matter, there are very few cases in which rates are suspended in which the finding of the Commission and is not made within the suspension period.
And the Commission has developed a practical matter -- method of expediting those cases.

They are very rigorous in postponements of time or extensions of times for pleadings and that sort of thing so that it's a practical matter in almost every instance in which a rate is protested and suspended.
The determination as to its reasonableness is made before the seven-month period of the suspension expires.
Now, that is not true in some agencies.

It's not true, for example, in the Federal Power Commission where it's unheard of to reach a decision within the five-month suspension period, but fortunately, motor carrier rate cases are much less complex than natural gas rate cases so that you do get.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Why does (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: bryce_rea_jr
turn.label: Mr. Bryce Rea, Jr.
turn.text: I don't know, Your Honor.
I think it was postponed for some time because the question of the constitutionality of the ton-mile tax was being litigated in New York.
Furthermore, the propriety of the surcharge on intrastate movements was before the New York Public Service Commission.

And the three proceedings, the proceeding on the surcharge for Intrastate Commerce before the New York Public Service Commission and the proceeding before the Interstate Commerce Commission and the court litigation with respect to the constitutionality of the ton-mile tax, all were more or less, rolling along together.
And as Your Honors all know, when you get several cases rolling together, it usually takes a longer time.
Thank you.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Mr. Rea, your answers to Justice Black, you will rely on Montana-Dakota?

turn.speaker: bryce_rea_jr
turn.label: Mr. Bryce Rea, Jr.
turn.text: We rely on Montana-Dakota.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: That's the basis for your (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: bryce_rea_jr
turn.label: Mr. Bryce Rea, Jr.
turn.text: That is the basis for our holding, Montana-Dakota, as it interprets the Federal Power Act, which as we read it --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: bryce_rea_jr
turn.label: Mr. Bryce Rea, Jr.
turn.text: -- is on all force substantively in its rate regulatory procedures with Part II of the Interstate Commerce Act.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes.
Now, do I -- do I understand that according to your reason, the dissent in that case did not reach that problem, did not object to that situation?

turn.speaker: bryce_rea_jr
turn.label: Mr. Bryce Rea, Jr.
turn.text: No, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: At which --

turn.speaker: bryce_rea_jr
turn.label: Mr. Bryce Rea, Jr.
turn.text: The dissent in that case was based on the allegation that the buyer of the service, Montana, had been fraudulently dominated by the seller of the service and therefore, was prevented by that fraud from availing himself of the remedies provided in the Act, namely, complaint with a request to the Commission to find the rate unreasonable.
In other words -- well, I think, here --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: That's alright.
It's alright.
You -- you made your point.

turn.speaker: bryce_rea_jr
turn.label: Mr. Bryce Rea, Jr.
turn.text: Thank you, Your Honor.
Thank you, gentlemen.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: We'll adjourn now.
